Title: PABLO ESPAÑOLA,petitioner,vs.VICENTE T. SINGSON, ET AL.,respondents.
Data:
Republic of the Philippines
SUPREME COURT
Manila


EN BANC


G.R. No. L-8724             April 13, 1956


PABLO ESPAÑOLA,
 petitioner,

vs.


VICENTE T. SINGSON, ET AL.,
 respondents.


Constancio Padilla and Gabriel Paringit for petitioner.

Lope P. Lopez and Madarang and Perez for respondents.


LABRADOR, 
J.
:


Petitioner Pablo Española is the offended party in two criminal cases pending in the justice of the peace court of Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya, Nos. 120 and 121, for less serious physical injuries and oral defamation, respectively. The accused in said criminal cases are the municipal mayor, a councilor and some policemen of the town. When these two criminal cases were called for trial before the Justice of Peace, respondent Vicente T. Singson, the accused challenged the right of counsel for petitioner to appear in the trial, alleging that petitioner had expressly reserved his right to present an indefendent civil action for damages arising from the offenses charged. Respondent Justice of the Peace sustained the objection of the accused, and upon denial by him of a motion for reconsidaration, the petitioner instituted the present action for 
certiorari
 to annul the order of the respondent Justice of the Peace denying him the right to appear by counsel in the said criminal cases.


The petition must be denied following our recent decision in the case of 
Gorospe, et al. vs. Gatmaitan
, et al., 
supra
, p. 600, where we said through Mr. Justice Bautista:




It therefore appears from the foregoing that an offended party loses his right to intervene in the presecution of a criminal case, not only when he was waived the civil action or expressly reserved his right to institute it, but also when he has actually instituted the civil action even if he has not made the waiver or reservation above adverted to. This ruling is further strengthened by article 33 of the new Civil Code which provides that "In case of defamation, fraud, and physical injuries, a civil action, may be tirely separate and distinct from the criminal action, may be brought by the injured party", and that such action may proceed independently of the criminal and for its determination preponderance of evidence would suffice. The present case comes within the purview of this provision.




The petition is hereby denied, with costs against the petitioner.


Bengzon, Paras, C.J., Padilla, Reyes, A., Jugo, Bautista Angelo, Concepcion, Reyes, J.B.L. and Endencia, JJ.,
 concur.
